item.title: FIFA Officials Arrested on Corruption Charges; Sepp Blatter Isn’t Among Them
item.description: As FIFA leaders gathered for a meeting, Swiss law enforcement officials arrived unannounced and made arrests at the Justice Department’s request on charges including racketeering and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Pascal Mora for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walter De Gregorio, the chief communication officer of FIFA, during a press conference at the FIFA headquarters in Zurich on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With New Resorts, Macau Places Its Bets on the Chinese Middle Class
item.description: New resorts aim to continue the former Portuguese colony’s transformation into a Chinese middle-class tourism center.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lion dancers performing at the opening of Galaxy Macau Phase II on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Tomb Robbers Used Feng Shui to Steal Antiquities
item.description: The police arrested 175 people across six provinces for theft and trafficking of $80 million worth of objects in what the government called the biggest antiquities trafficking case in the history of the People’s Republic.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Migrants Rescued From the Sea Face Uncertainty in Indonesian Camps
item.description: Aid groups are concerned that the conditions in the camps are unsanitary, could potentially spread disease, and were never intended for long-term habitation.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bangladeshi migrants at a shelter in Langsa, Indonesia. Indonesia and Malaysia have agreed to take in roughly 7,000 migrants for up to a year.

item.title: Jason Rezaian Trial in Iran May Be More About Leverage Than Justice
item.description: The fates of Americans imprisoned in Iran have often centered on how the country’s negotiations with the United States are going.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: European Union Asks Member Countries to Accept Quotas of Migrants
item.description: The appeal by the European Commission is a response to fears that southern countries will be overwhelmed by the influx of people crossing the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Afghan migrants arrived on the Greek island of Kos by inflatable boat on Wednesday.

item.title: David Cameron Sets Course for Britain Amid Pageantry of Queen’s Speech
item.description: The British prime minister addressed issues including a referendum on European Union membership and a measure seeking to curb immigration.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth arriving for the State Opening of Parliament in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Axact Chief Executive Arrested in Pakistan Over Fake Diplomas Scandal
item.description: The arrests were a sharp blow to a company that claimed to be Pakistan’s biggest software exporter and was on the cusp of starting a major television network.
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Heirs of the ‘Secret War’ in Laos
item.description: For Laotian-Americans of my generation, the psychic traumas of our parents are wrapped in our DNA.
item.dc:creator: MAI DER VANG
item.media:description: Laotian fighters and trucks laden with ammunition at the Long Tieng air base in 1972. Less than three years later, thousands of people would be abandoned at the airstrip.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Malaysia’s Duty to the Rohingyas
item.description: As an Asean member, it must use its influence over Myanmar to help the refugees.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: What About Sepp Blatter? And Other Questions About the FIFA Case
item.description: Questions remain after the arrests of several high-ranking members of soccer’s governing body. Here’s what you need to know about the charges and the accused.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: FIFA, a multibillion-dollar organization that governs soccer but has been plagued by accusations of bribery for decades, had several top officials arrested early Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Allies to Tie North Korea’s Rights Record to Nuclear Talks
item.description: The United States, Japan and South Korea are calling for more pressure on North Korea to curb its nuclear ambitions, including more effective sanctions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The top nuclear envoys, from left, Junichi Ihara of Japan, Hwang Joon-kook of South Korea and Sung Kim of the United States at a meeting in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Reports About 200 Million Fewer Hungry People Than in 1990
item.description: The global count of hungry people has fallen from about one billion 25 years ago to 795 million today, the United Nations says, or about one person out of every nine.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Most Hong Kongers Support Banning Ivory Sales, Poll Finds
item.description: A survey found that ivory was unpopular among residents in Hong Kong, despite the city being a major market for ivory, much of it illegal.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:description: Ivory tusks from Kenya seized by Hong Kong customs officials, displayed on Jan. 4, 2013.

item.title: FIFA Officials Arrested on Corruption Charges; Blatter Isn’t Among Them
item.description: As FIFA leaders gathered for a meeting, Swiss law enforcement officials arrived unannounced and made arrests at the Justice Department’s request on charges including racketeering and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Pascal Mora for The New York Times
item.media:description: FIFA officials were escorted out behind sheets at the Baur au Lac hotel in Zurich.

item.title: Hamas Is Accused of Using Gaza War as Cover to Torture and Kill Palestinians
item.description: An Amnesty International report on last summer’s Gaza war says there were at least 23 extrajudicial killings of Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israel.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Qaeda Member Pleads Guilty in Brooklyn on Terrorism Charges
item.description: Saddiq Al-Abbadi, who led a firefight in Afghanistan in 2008 that killed an Army Ranger, faces a possible penalty of life in prison when he is sentenced later this year.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: World Briefing: Austria: Youth Guilty in Bomb Plot
item.description: An Austrian court has found a 14-year-old boy guilty of planning to blow up Vienna’s main railway station after being radicalized by Islamic extremists.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Suriname: Despite Checkered Past, President Seems Set for New Term
item.description: President Desi Bouterse, a former military leader convicted in 1999 in the Netherlands of drug trafficking, appeared to be on course for a second term in Suriname.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Michoacán Killings Prompt Human Rights Inquiry
item.description: The National Human Rights Commission has opened an investigation into the killing of 42 people last week in a confrontation with the federal police.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
